formdata.value: Autonomous driving requires highly accurate perception, decision-making, and navigation in complex and dynamic environments. Current systems face challenges in real-time accuracy, adaptability to diverse weather and lighting conditions, and safe decision-making in unpredictable traffic scenarios.

A deep learning–driven computer vision pipeline integrating:

Image recognition (CNN-based, VGGNet-like)

Real-time target tracking & classification (multi-task loss for classification + bounding box regression)

Environment perception & decision support (Double DQN reinforcement learning)

Path planning & navigation (Graph Neural Networks + A* search with real-time updates)

Pros: High accuracy (>98%), millisecond-level response, robust in varied scenarios.

Cons: Slightly lower accuracy in environmental perception (97.8%), high computational requirements, and dependence on large, annotated datasets.

Architecture is modular and can be scaled to integrate additional sensors or adapt to different traffic environments. However, scalability to highly complex or novel environments may require further training and tuning.

While explicit cybersecurity steps are not discussed, the system’s robustness relies on redundancy from multi-sensor fusion (camera, radar, lidar) and rigorous real-world validation to mitigate misclassification and unsafe decisions.

Clear modular separation of functional components (perception, decision-making, navigation) supports easier updates, retraining, and integration of new deep learning models without full system redesign.

body.raw:
{
    "answer":"Data Quality, Bias Mitigation & Adaptation to Scarce Labeled Data

Data Quality – Automated annotation validation, cross-checks by multiple annotators, and active learning to flag uncertain samples.
Bias Mitigation – Balanced datasets across weather, lighting, geographic regions; fairness audits on model outputs.
Adaptation to Scarce Data – Use of transfer learning from large-scale vision models, synthetic data generation from simulators, and semi-supervised learning for unlabeled data.
Continuous Learning – Online model updates and incremental fine-tuning as new environments are encountered."
    }
